questions.text: A 51-year-old man presents to the ophthalmologist for evaluation of double vision. He reports intermittent horizontal diplopia over the past two weeks that worsens as the day progresses, especially with reading. He has felt more fatigued lately, particularly in the evenings. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medication. He has myopia, for which his lens prescription has not changed. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg., oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Examination reveals bilateral ptosis that becomes more pronounced with sustained upward gaze and difficulty getting up from the chair. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Numbness and tingling of the limbs

questions.solution:
This 51-year-old man presents with signs and symptoms of generalized myasthenic gravis, as evidenced by intermittent diplopia and fatigable ptosis, that worsens by the end of the day and proximal muscle weakness. A focused history may also reveal difficulty chewing and swallowing secondary to bulbar weakness.        

Myasthenia gravis is a progressive autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder that causes fatigable weakness in skeletal muscles. Patients may report worsening symptoms with sustained or repeated muscle activity, like looking up. Hypophonic or dysarthric speech, neck weakness, and fluctuating limb weakness may be present.        

Physical examination may show ptosis with sustained upward gaze, reduced ability to keep cheeks puffed with air, fatigable speech with counting, and difficulty holding the upper extremities above the head. Since this condition is limited to the neuromuscular junction, the sensory examination and deep tendon reflexes will be normal.   

Option Analysis

✅ Difficulty chewing and swallowing:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Dry mouth:
Incorrect: This patient presents signs and symptoms of generalized myasthenia gravis, which may present with difficulty with chewing and swallowing and excess drooling, rather than dry mouth.  
❌ Distal muscle weakness:
Incorrect: This patient presents with signs and symptoms of generalized myasthenia gravis, with evidence of proximal muscle weakness. The distal muscles are usually spared. 
❌ Absent deep tendon reflexes:
Incorrect: This patient presents with signs and symptoms of generalized myasthenia gravis, which affects the neuromuscular junction. The sensory examination and deep tendon reflexes will be normal. 
❌ Numbness and tingling of the limbs:
Incorrect: This patient presents with signs and symptoms of generalized myasthenia gravis, which affects the neuromuscular junction, and does not result in paresthesia.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to a primary care clinic for follow-up of a chronic cough. He has experienced a persistent, dry cough for the past six months despite the use of inhaled bronchodilators, inhaled steroids, oral steroids, and antibiotics. He also reports blood-tinged sputum for the past month. On review of systems, he endorses weakness that makes it difficult to get out of bed in the morning, but his strength improves as the day goes on. He additionally notes constipation. He has no other known medical problems, but he does have a 30 pack-year tobacco history. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg. On exam, he appears alert with an intermittent cough. There is bilateral facial muscle weakness, neck flexor weakness, and weakness with shoulder abduction and hip flexion. Sensation is normal throughout. Which of the following diagnostic test results is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: An incremental response to repetitive nerve stimulation
Serum antibodies against low-density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4)
Serum antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (anti-AChR)

questions.solution:
Adapted from Kouyoumdijan and de Paula Estephan 2023. 

This patient’s fluctuating, painless muscle weakness in the setting of a potential lung malignancy is concerning for Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome. This condition occurs due to paraneoplastic antibodies directed against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels. Electrodiagnostic studies, including electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies (NCS), help confirm the diagnosis. In Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, an incremental response to repetitive nerve stimulation would be expected.

The differential diagnosis for a patient with a suspected neuromuscular junction disorder depends on whether the symptoms fluctuate. Symptoms that worsen with repetitive use suggest myasthenia gravis, whereas symptoms that improve with repeated use suggest Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome. Diagnostic tools that can help differentiate between these conditions include an ice pack test, NCS, EMG, and serum antibodies.

Nonfluctuating weakness is seen in both botulism and organophosphate toxicity. EMG and NCS can be similarly helpful in differentiating these two disorders, but the clinical history and physical examination are often more useful.
   

Option Analysis

✅ An incremental response to repetitive nerve stimulation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Serum antibodies against low-density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4):
Incorrect: Anti-LRP4 antibodies are associated with myasthenia gravis. However, this patient’s presentation is more concerning for Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, a neuromuscular junction disorder caused by paraneoplastic antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels (anti-VGCC).
❌ Serum antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (anti-AChR):
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is concerning for Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, a neuromuscular junction disorder secondary to paraneoplastic antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels (anti-VGCC). Anti-AChR antibodies are seen with myasthenia gravis.
❌ Positive Clostridium botulinum stool culture:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms of weakness and chronic cough in the setting of chronic tobacco use are concerning for Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, a fluctuating neuromuscular junction disorder. Infection with Clostridium botulinum, or botulism, is associated with nonfluctuating, progressive weakness.
❌ Elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) protein level:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms are concerning for Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, a neuromuscular junction disorder that occurs secondary to paraneoplastic antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels. An elevated CSF protein level would be more consistent with Guillain-Barré syndrome.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of unsteadiness and frequent near-falls. Since returning home from visiting his grandchildren two weeks ago, he has experienced numbness and tingling in the left leg and foot. There is also back pain that occasionally shoots down the left leg. Past medical history includes well-controlled diabetes mellitus treated with insulin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 122/76 mmHg. On physical examination, there is weakness of the left hip with both abduction and extension; weakness of the left ankle with dorsiflexion, eversion, and inversion; and weakness of the left toes with extension. There is sensory loss over the left anterolateral tibia and dorsum of the foot. On gait assessment, the patient lifts the left leg noticeably higher than the right, bending the hip and knee more with each step to keep the toes from catching on the floor. Which of the following historical elements, if present, would best narrow the differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with unsteadiness and near-falls and walks with a steppage (or high-stepping) gait pattern in which foot drop is offset by excessive hip flexion. Typically, without a family history of similar gait problems, the main considerations are peroneal neuropathy and L5 radiculopathy. The combination of numbness, tingling, and weakness in the sensory and distribution of the L5 nerve root points to possible compression by a herniated disc, a common consequence of back injury.

Assessing gait patterns in patients with gait unsteadiness or falls helps narrow the differential diagnosis and guide further testing. The history should cover birth and developmental history, past medical and surgical history, social and family history, and any history of trauma or injury. Associated symptoms (e.g., numbness, tingling, pain) can also suggest a specific etiology. The physical examination should include an assessment of muscle strength, sensory function, reflexes, coordination, and gait.
   

Option Analysis

✅ History of a back injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of a knee injury:
Incorrect: A knee injury might cause peroneal neuropathy and a steppage gait. However, this patient’s weakness with ankle inversion, hip abduction, and hip extension suggests L5 radiculopathy, which could result from a herniated disc due to a back injury.
❌ History of vitamin B12 deficiency:
Incorrect: This patient presents with a steppage gait pattern (i.e., excessive hip flexion, high steps, foot drop) rather than the stomping gait pattern (i.e., wide-based, unsteady, forceful steps) associated with subacute combined degeneration from vitamin B12 deficiency. This patient’s weakness with ankle inversion, hip abduction, and hip extension suggests L5 radiculopathy, which could occur because of a herniated disc from a back injury.
❌ History of perinatal brain injury:
Incorrect: This patient presents with a steppage gait pattern (i.e., excessive hip flexion, high steps, foot drop) rather than the spastic gait pattern (i.e., stiff legs, poor floor clearance, circumduction of legs) associated with cerebral palsy from a perinatal brain injury. This patient’s weakness with ankle inversion, hip abduction, and hip extension suggests L5 radiculopathy, which could occur because of a herniated disc from a back injury.
❌ Family history of similar symptoms:
Incorrect: This patient presents with a steppage gait pattern that can be seen with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, a genetic distal motor-sensory neuropathy. However, this patient’s weakness with hip abduction and hip extension suggests L5 radiculopathy, which could occur because of a herniated disc related to a back injury.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of numbness and pain in the medial ankle and sole of the right foot. The symptoms worsen with prolonged standing and walking. Past medical history is noncontributory, and the patient takes no medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. The patient endorses sensory loss to light touch over the sole of the right foot. No weakness is noted with dorsiflexion or eversion of the right ankle. Which of the following would be consistent with the underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: Recent use of a long leg cast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of a compressive neuropathy, specifically tibial neuropathy at the ankle. The numbness and pain in the medial ankle and sole of the foot, worsened by repetitive use, support this diagnosis. Sensory loss may be noted on the plantar surface of the foot, as well as weakness with toe flexion.

Compressive neuropathies occur due to mechanical entrapment of peripheral nerves, resulting in paresthesias, pain, or weakness. Without treatment, this can lead to demyelination and axonal injury. The patient will describe specific patterns of numbness, tingling, pain, or difficulty with specific motor tasks, depending on the site of injury.

To differentiate between mononeuropathies, it is important to understand the motor and sensory function of each peripheral nerve. Peroneal nerve entrapment may cause foot drop, toe dragging (due to weakness with toe extension), and paresthesia in the lateral shin and the dorsum of the foot. Tibial neuropathy causes paresthesia in the medial ankle and sole of the foot, with or without weakness of toe flexion.

Option Analysis

✅ Weakness of toe flexion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent use of a long leg cast:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of tibial neuropathy at the ankle. Use of a long leg cast is more likely to result in peroneal neuropathy, which can cause sensory loss in the lateral shin and dorsum of the foot, as well as weakness in toe extension, ankle dorsiflexion, and foot eversion.
❌ Knee trauma:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of tibial neuropathy at the ankle. A history of knee trauma is more likely to result in peroneal neuropathy, which can cause sensory loss in the lateral shin and dorsum of the foot, as well as weakness in toe extension, ankle dorsiflexion, and foot eversion.
❌ Prolonged leg crossing:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of tibial neuropathy at the ankle. Prolonged leg crossing is more likely to result in peroneal neuropathy, which can cause sensory loss in the lateral shin and dorsum of the foot, as well as weakness in toe extension, ankle dorsiflexion, and foot eversion.
❌ Repetitive squatting exercises:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of tibial neuropathy at the ankle. Repetitive squatting exercises are more likely to result in peroneal neuropathy, which can cause sensory loss in the lateral shin and dorsum of the foot, as well as weakness in toe extension, ankle dorsiflexion, and foot eversion.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the primary care clinic for evaluation of frequent falls. There has been gradually worsening weakness over the past 10 years. It has become increasingly difficult to rise from a chair or climb stairs without using the railing. There have been more frequent episodes of tripping. The patient’s partner reports new-onset snoring during sleep. Medical history includes well-controlled hypertension treated with lisinopril. Family history is notable for a sibling who died in infancy due to respiratory failure. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 122/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals proximal lower extremity weakness, bilateral thigh atrophy, and areflexia. Which additional symptom or physical examination finding is also most likely to be present?

choices.text: Tingling sensation in the lower extremities

questions.solution:
This 44-year-old patient presents with slowly progressive proximal bilateral lower extremity weakness, as evidenced by difficulty standing and climbing stairs, along with areflexia. In addition, there is a family history of a sibling with respiratory failure in infancy. These findings raise concern for spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) type 4. Bulbar involvement is common in motor neuron disease and may manifest as difficulty swallowing.

In evaluating a patient with suspected motor neuron disease, it is essential to assess for sensory involvement through history and physical examination. The presence of sensory deficits suggests an alternative diagnosis, as motor neuron diseases typically spare sensory pathways. Patients may report weakness of the face, neck, arms, or legs. As these conditions progress, weakness may affect muscles involved in speech, swallowing, and respiration.

Motor neuron diseases can involve upper motor neurons originating in the cerebral cortex or lower motor neurons located in the brainstem and anterior horn of the spinal cord. Lower motor neuron signs include muscle atrophy, fasciculations, hyporeflexia, and decreased tone. Upper motor neuron signs include spasticity and hyperreflexia. Examples of lower motor neuron diseases include SMA type 4, which progresses gradually over years. In contrast, a rapidly progressive illness following a febrile respiratory or gastrointestinal infection may suggest acute flaccid myelitis. The presence of both upper and lower motor neuron signs is characteristic of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

Option Analysis

✅ Difficulty swallowing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Numbness in the lower extremities:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of motor neuron disease, likely spinal muscular atrophy type 4, which does not involve sensory pathways. As the disease progresses, difficulty swallowing may develop due to bulbar muscle weakness.
❌ Tingling sensation in the lower extremities:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of motor neuron disease, likely spinal muscular atrophy type 4, which does not involve sensory pathways. As the disease progresses, difficulty swallowing may develop due to bulbar muscle weakness.
❌ Emotional lability:
Incorrect: Emotional lability or pseudobulbar affect may be seen in motor neuron diseases with upper motor neuron involvement, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. This feature is not typical of spinal muscular atrophy, which affects only lower motor neurons.
❌ Bilateral hand weakness:
Incorrect: While hand weakness may occur later in the course of this patient’s disease, early symptoms of spinal muscular atrophy typically involve proximal muscles of the lower extremities. Bulbar or respiratory involvement is more likely to develop before distal upper limb weakness.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents to urgent care for evaluation of left-sided facial droop for the past few hours. He was eating dinner with his partner when she noticed he was drooling slightly on the left side and his speech was slurred. They observed that the right side of his face was drooping compared to the left. There is no history of recent falls. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia, which are all well-controlled with medication. Temperature is 37°C, (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 148/92 mmHg. Weight is 104 kg (229 lb.), and height is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in). Physical examination shows an asymmetric smile with mild drooling and dysarthria. The patient is sensitive to tuning fork stimulation on the right side. Point-of-care glucose is 150 mg/dL. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Non-contrast computed tomography (CT) of the head
Assessment of frontalis and orbicularis oculi function bilaterally
Examination of the skin and external auditory canal on the left side
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head without contrast

questions.solution:
In this patient with unilateral facial droop, drooling, and slurred speech, an initial evaluation should be performed to determine if the upper part of the face (forehead) is involved in the deficit or spared. This will help determine if the deficit is central or peripheral and will guide further management. This can be performed through assessment of frontalis and orbicularis oculi function bilaterally. Forehead sparing indicates a central lesion whereas involvement of the forehead and eye indicates a peripheral cranial nerve VII lesion.            

Patients presenting with symptoms of weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles, with or without impaired taste sensation, hyperacusis, or impaired lacrimation or salivation, should be evaluated with a focused physical examination, to determine whether the upper part of the face is involved. Assessment should include whether there is movement of the forehead, eyebrow sagging, or inability to raise the eyebrow or close the eye.       

Upper motor neuron innervation is bilateral for the upper facial muscles and unilateral for the lower facial muscles. Therefore, forehead sparing is indicative of an upper motor neuron lesion, or central cause, which warrants prompt neuroimaging. A brain MRI is preferred given its lack of associated radiation exposure. Once a central etiology is suspected, further neurodiagnostic investigations can identify the underlying etiology; these may include CSF analysis in the case of infection or demyelination or a blood culture or biopsy in the case of an abscess or tumor.        

When the forehead is involved in the deficit and there is weakness in both the upper and lower portions of the face on the involved side, this indicates peripheral facial palsy. Further investigation for a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerves should be performed. Peripheral facial nerve palsy can be caused by Guillain-Barre syndrome, Lyme disease, Ramsay-Hund syndrome, or Bell palsy.  



Option Analysis

❌ Non-contrast computed tomography (CT) of the head  :
Incorrect: While acute ischemia and intracranial hemorrhage are in the differential diagnosis for this patient with stroke risk factors and a unilateral facial droop, this patient may have a peripheral cranial nerve VII palsy, which could be determined by initially performing a more robust physical examination including assessment of the frontalis and orbicularis oculi function bilaterally to determine if there is forehead involvement indicating a peripheral nerve palsy. 
✅ Assessment of frontalis and orbicularis oculi function bilaterally:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Oral corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids are used in the management of idiopathic peripheral cranial nerve VII palsy (Bell palsy). While this is in the differential diagnosis, a detailed evaluation to determine if there is forehead sparing is necessary since this would indicate upper motor nerve involvement necessitating brain imaging.  
❌ Examination of the skin and external auditory canal on the left side:
Incorrect: Examination of the skin may reveal skin lesions consistent with left-sided herpes zoster Oticus (Ramsay Hunt syndrome), which can cause peripheral cranial nerve VIII deficit because of its proximity to cranial nerve VII ipsilateral facial paralysis. However, evaluation of upper motor nerve involvement with assessment of frontalis and orbicularis oculi function to determine if the deficit is central or peripheral should be performed first. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head without contrast:
Incorrect: MRI of the brain would help determine the cause of central etiologies of unilateral facial palsy but would be unnecessary in a patient with evidence of peripheral cranial nerve VII palsy. Therefore, this patient should first have an assessment of frontalis and orbicularis oculi function bilaterally to determine if the palsy is central or peripheral.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man has been hospitalized in the medical intensive care unit for the past 45 days due to complications related to sepsis. For the past week, he has had trouble moving in bed as well as symmetric proximal muscle weakness. His past medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by neuropathy, hypertension, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He is currently receiving cefepime, insulin lispro, gabapentin, lisinopril, and omeprazole. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 8/min and labored, blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 87% on room air. On examination, the patient appears drowsy but awakens easily. Lungs are clear to auscultation. There is significant weakness with neck flexion and bilateral shoulder abduction. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient, who has had a prolonged intensive care unit course, has developed progressive, symmetric, and painless weakness, raising concern for critical illness myopathy. Because this condition can compromise the muscles of respiration, assessing respiratory muscle strength is essential. This patient’s hypoxia, bradypnea, and labored breathing suggest impending respiratory failure, making endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation the most appropriate next step.        

The initial management of an unstable patient suspected of having a muscle disease, such as critical illness myopathy, is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. Securing the airway with endotracheal intubation and providing mechanical ventilation may be necessary in cases of respiratory compromise. It is also important to establish intravenous access, as parenteral fluids and medications may be needed. Continuous monitoring of vital signs, particularly respiratory rate, heart rate, pulse oximetry, blood pressure, and cardiac telemetry, is essential. Once the patient is stabilized, additional evaluations and diagnostics can be performed.   

Option Analysis

✅ Intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Chest radiography:
Incorrect: Chest radiography is helpful in evaluating respiratory distress, but only after the immediate stabilization of the patient’s airway and breathing. This patient presents with signs and symptoms of impending respiratory failure due to critical illness myopathy, making endotracheal intubation the priority. 
❌ Repeat blood culture:
Incorrect: While repeating a blood culture can help determine if antimicrobial coverage is adequate, it should be deferred until after the patient’s airway and breathing are stabilized. 
❌ Serum creatine kinase:
Incorrect: A creatine kinase level can be nonspecifically abnormal in patients presenting with weakness. However, the urgent need is to assess and secure this patient’s respiratory function. 
❌ Broadening of intravenous antimicrobial coverage:
Incorrect: Broadening antimicrobial coverage may be appropriate for a deteriorating patient with respiratory distress in the intensive care unit, but only after immediate stabilization of their airway and breathing.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of weakness. For the past year, she has noticed gradually progressive, persistent weakness. She has increasing difficulty combing her hair and getting out of a chair. Her past medical history includes major depressive disorder for which she takes citalopram. There is no family history of similar symptoms. The patient's temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. On physical exam, she is alert and has normal facial muscle strength. There is weakness with bilateral shoulder abduction and hip flexion. Reddish-purplish papules are present over the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints of the fingers on both hands, and the skin appears rough, with cracking. Sensation is intact throughout. Which of the following additional features is most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Abnormal left ventricular function on echocardiography
Worsening of symptoms in cold temperatures

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symmetric, bilateral, predominantly proximal weakness and a normal sensory exam; this presentation is concerning for an inflammatory myopathy. Evaluating for cutaneous findings, including a heliotrope rash, can help differentiate between polymyositis and dermatomyositis. Additional cutaneous findings seen in dermatomyositis include Gottron papules (small purplish plaques on extensor surfaces), the V-sign (V-shaped rash on the upper neck and chest, also known as the “shawl sign”), and mechanic’s hands (rough, cracking skin on the fingers and fingertips).       

The differential diagnosis of a patient with suspected muscle disease includes hereditary and nonhereditary causes. Inherited etiologies may be further subdivided based on the tempo of symptoms, with some disorders being episodic in nature (e.g. periodic paralyses) and others being persistent and progressive (e.g. muscular and myotonic dystrophies). Among the nonhereditary causes, the differential diagnosis can be narrowed based on the pattern of weakness in the upper extremities, with some disorders affecting the proximal musculature primarily (e.g., statin-induced myopathy, inflammatory myopathies), and other disorders affecting the distal musculature predominantly (e.g. inclusion body myositis).        

In cases where the history and physical examination are not diagnostic, further testing (e.g., muscle biopsy, serum testing) may be necessary. A muscle biopsy is very important in distinguishing between polymyositis (characterized by endomysial inflammation), dermatomyositis (marked by perifascicular and perimysial inflammation), and inclusion body myositis (which features rimmed vacuoles in the myofibers).    

Option Analysis

✅ Heliotrope rash:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Abnormal serum potassium level:
Incorrect: Both hypo- and hyperkalemic periodic paralysis are on the differential for a patient presenting with episodic weakness. This patient’s persistent weakness, accompanied by dermatologic findings consistent with Gottron papules and mechanic’s hands, suggests an inflammatory myopathy, specifically dermatomyositis, which is associated with a heliotrope rash. 
❌ Abnormal left ventricular function on echocardiography:
Incorrect: A muscular dystrophy may be accompanied by cardiomyopathy, but this patient does not have any cardiac symptoms or a positive family history of muscle disease. This patient is more likely to have a nonhereditary etiology, and the dermatologic findings consistent with Gottron papules and mechanic’s hands suggest dermatomyositis, which is associated with a heliotrope rash. 
❌ Worsening of symptoms in cold temperatures:
Incorrect: Myotonic dystrophy, a hereditary form of weakness, can feature worsening of symptoms in cold temperatures. However, this patient does not have a family history suggesting this, and the dermatologic findings consistent with Gottron papules and mechanic’s hands suggest dermatomyositis, which is associated with a heliotrope rash. 
❌ Use of a statin:
Incorrect: This patient does not have a known history of conditions requiring statin therapy, making a statin-induced myopathy unlikely. Proximal muscle weakness, in the absence of a positive family history of similar symptoms, along with the presence of dermatologic findings, suggests dermatomyositis, associated with a heliotrope rash.

questions.text: A 19-year-old individual comes to the emergency department for evaluation of weakness. Yesterday morning, they awoke feeling weak in both legs, which intensified throughout the day. This morning, the patient fell while attempting to get into the shower. When calling their employer to report their delayed arrival, the patient was told their voice sounded slurred. There is no past medical history, and no medications are taken. The patient had vomiting and diarrhea for three days with accompanying fever beginning 10 days ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 10/min, blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. On exam, the patient is drooling and dysarthric, with bilateral flaccid lower extremities and intact sensation. Patellar reflexes are diminished. No signs of trauma are present. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine

questions.solution:
This 19-year-old patient presents with rapidly progressive symptoms concerning for acute flaccid myelitis, including bilateral lower extremity weakness, decreased muscle tone, and hyporeflexia following a febrile gastrointestinal illness. Vital signs and the presence of drooling on examination suggest compromised airway and breathing, likely due to involvement of the respiratory and bulbar muscles. The first priority is stabilization with intubation and mechanical ventilation.

Acute flaccid myelitis (AFM) is a motor neuron lesion characterized by sudden-onset weakness, often preceded by a febrile respiratory or gastrointestinal illness. Hospital admission is typically required due to the potential for rapid neurological deterioration and respiratory failure. Motor neuron disease can affect upper motor neurons from the cerebral cortex or lower motor neurons in the brainstem and anterior horn of the spinal cord. AFM primarily involves lower motor neurons, leading to muscle atrophy, hypotonia, and hyporeflexia.

Initial management begins with an ABCDE assessment to determine stability. If unstable, focus on airway, breathing, and circulation, which may require intubation and mechanical ventilation. Establish intravenous (IV) access, consider IV fluids, and initiate continuous monitoring of vital signs, including heart rate, blood pressure, oxygen saturation, and cardiac rhythm. Administer supplemental oxygen as indicated.

Option Analysis

✅ Intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine:
Incorrect: MRI may aid in the evaluation of suspected acute flaccid myelitis but should not precede assessment and stabilization of airway, breathing, and circulation. Drooling, hypoxia, and a reduced respiratory rate are concerning for respiratory failure and require immediate intervention.
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis:
Incorrect: CSF analysis may assist in the evaluation of acute flaccid myelitis but is not the priority in the setting of signs of respiratory compromise. Airway protection and respiratory support must take precedence.
❌ Intravenous (IV) tissue plasminogen activator (tPA):
Incorrect: This presentation is more consistent with acute flaccid myelitis than acute ischemic stroke, and the onset of symptoms falls well outside the treatment window for tPA. Additionally, clinical signs of respiratory failure must be addressed emergently.
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head:
Incorrect: While neuroimaging may be useful in evaluating neurological symptoms, this patient exhibits signs of respiratory insufficiency requiring immediate stabilization. Imaging should follow once the airway and breathing are secured.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of left foot weakness. The patient works as a nurse and routinely wears compression stockings due to spending much of the day on his feet. During a shift the previous evening, the patient spent much of the time at the computer reading articles, with his left leg crossed over his right leg. The patient immediately went to sleep when returning home after the shift. Past medical history is noncontributory, and no medications are taken daily. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. On examination, there is weakness with left ankle dorsiflexion, foot eversion, and great toe extension, with a loss of sensation in the lateral shin and dorsum of the left foot. Foot inversion strength is normal. A steppage gait pattern is present. Patellar and Achilles reflexes are 2+ and symmetric, and upper extremity strength is normal. Based on the history and physical examination findings, which of the following is the most likely site of pathology?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a left foot drop, manifesting as weakness with dorsiflexion and eversion of the foot, weakness of great toe extension, a loss of sensation in the lateral shin and dorsum of the foot, and a steppage gait with normal reflexes. The history of using compressive stockings and sustained leg crossing suggests peroneal neuropathy, a peripheral nerve lesion.        

To differentiate between peripheral nerve, nerve root, and plexus lesions, history and physical findings are key. Peripheral neuropathies are usually unilateral, affecting strength and sensation in a specific nerve distribution, and may be caused by trauma, repetitive use, or compression. Nerve root lesions (radiculopathies) typically present with unilateral weakness and sensory loss in a specific dermatome. Plexopathies cause multifocal deficits, affecting multiple areas innervated by the same plexus, and may involve patchy sensory loss and motor weakness across different regions.        

Reflexes can be normal, reduced, or absent in peripheral nerve, nerve root, or plexopathy lesions, depending on which nerves are affected. Additional symptoms like back pain, radicular pain, or bowel/bladder incontinence may help further localize the site of pathology.   

Option Analysis

✅ Peripheral nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Nerve root:
Incorrect: While an L5 radiculopathy can also present with foot drop, it typically causes weakness in both foot inversion and eversion. This patient has isolated foot eversion weakness with preserved inversion, suggesting a common peroneal neuropathy rather than an L5 radiculopathy. 
❌ Plexus:
Incorrect: A lumbosacral plexopathy would typically cause more extensive lower extremity involvement, including patchy sensory loss, weakness, and decreased or absent reflexes. The findings in this case are isolated to the common peroneal nerve distribution, making a plexopathy unlikely.
❌ Spinal cord:
Incorrect: A spinal cord lesion could potentially cause unilateral weakness, but it would typically affect a larger portion of the leg, and it would more likely present with bilateral symptoms and upper motor neuron signs, such as hyperreflexia and spasticity. This patient’s isolated, unilateral foot drop with normal reflexes is more consistent with a peripheral nerve lesion.
❌ Brain:
Incorrect: Central nervous system (CNS) lesions (e.g. stroke) usually cause weakness and sensory loss that affect larger areas of the body. Additionally, CNS lesions are often associated with other signs like facial weakness, speech disturbances, or cortical deficits. Reflex abnormalities may also be present. This patient’s isolated, unilateral foot drop and nerve-specific sensory loss distribution make a peripheral nerve lesion more likely.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmologist for evaluation of double vision. She complains of intermittent horizontal diplopia over the past two weeks that worsens as the day progresses, especially with looking up. In the evenings, her eyelids become droopy despite not feeling tired. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medication. She has astigmatism but does not require prescription lenses. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 12/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97 on room air. On exam, there is bilateral ptosis that worsens with sustained upward gaze. Improvement of ptosis is seen after the application of ice packs over the eyes for two minutes. Bilateral limb strength, deep tendon reflexes, and sensory exam are normal. Laboratory testing for disease-specific antibodies is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to obtain now?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the orbits
Computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the head

questions.solution:
This 37-year-old woman presents with signs and symptoms of ocular myasthenia gravis, as evidenced by intermittent diplopia, fatigable ptosis, and a positive ice test. Patients with ocular manifestations are less likely to test positive for disease-specific antibodies. For these patients, a nerve conduction study with repetitive nerve stimulation may be confirmatory.        

In patients with ocular or generalized myasthenia gravis with ocular symptoms, bedside testing can be performed. Application of an ice pack to the eyelids for at least two minutes can enhance neuromuscular transmission and improve ptosis. A bedside intravenous injection of an acetylcholinesterase like edrophonium, that leads to improved muscle strength can also help diagnose myasthenia gravis.        

Disease-specific antibodies include anti-acetylcholine binding, blocking, and modulating antibodies, as well as anti-muscle specific kinase and anti-low-density lipoprotein receptor-related antibodies. Nerve conduction study (NCS) and electromyography (EMG) will show electrodecrement with repetitive nerve stimulation, and increased jitter.   

Option Analysis

✅ Nerve conduction study (NCS) and electromyography (EMG):
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Incorrect: While a brain MRI may be helpful in the evaluation of diplopia, this patient’s fatigable ptosis and improvement with a neuromuscular junction enhancer (i.e., ice) suggests ocular myasthenia gravis for which neuroimaging is typically normal. In the absence of antibodies, a nerve conduction study and electromyography can confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the orbits:
Incorrect: This patient’s fatigable ptosis and improvement with a neuromuscular junction enhancer such as ice suggests ocular myasthenia gravis, for which ocular imaging would be normal. 
❌ Computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the head:
Incorrect: This patient has bilateral, fatigable symptoms, making an aneurysmal compressive lesion of the third cranial nerve (CN-III) unlikely. A nerve conduction study and electromyography can be diagnostic while preventing exposure to unnecessary radiation. In patients with ocular symptoms but negative antibody tests. 
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis:
Incorrect: While bilateral ptosis may occur with Miller-Fischer variant Guillain-Barre syndrome, this patient’s normal extremity strength and intact deep tendon reflexes make this diagnosis unlikely. In patients with ocular symptoms in the absence of autoantibodies, a nerve conduction study and electromyography can be helpful for diagnosing ocular myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the neurology clinic for evaluation of weakness. For the past several years, he has noticed gradually progressive, persistent weakness of both hands, leading to difficulty opening jars, dressing, and writing. These symptoms do not change throughout the day. His past medical history includes hypertension, for which he takes lisinopril. There is no family history of similar symptoms. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/85 mmHg. On physical exam, he is alert and has normal facial muscle strength. No abnormal skin lesions are present. Bilateral muscle weakness is noted, particularly in finger flexion, knee extension, and dorsiflexion of the feet. Atrophy of the quadriceps is also observed. Sensation is intact throughout. Which of the following additional diagnostic tests can help confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 60-year-old patient presents with symmetric, slowly progressive, predominantly distal, bilateral weakness with a normal sensory exam, which is concerning for a muscle disease—specifically inclusion body myositis. A muscle biopsy can confirm the diagnosis by revealing rimmed vacuoles in myofibers.        

The differential diagnosis of a patient suspected of having a muscle disease can be narrowed based on family history, tempo of symptoms, and pattern of muscle weakness (e.g. proximal versus distal muscle weakness). In cases where the diagnosis is unclear or further confirmation is needed, a muscle biopsy and/or genetic testing may be warranted.   





Option Analysis

✅ Muscle biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Sequencing of the CACNA1S or SCN4A genes:
Incorrect: Both hypo- and hyperkalemic periodic paralysis are in the differential for a patient presenting with weakness. However, this patient’s persistent, predominantly distal weakness suggests inclusion body myositis, which can be confirmed with a muscle biopsy. 
❌ Deletion/duplication analysis of the DMD gene:
Incorrect: Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies are in the differential for a patient presenting with weakness. However, this patient’s age and persistent, predominantly distal weakness suggest inclusion body myositis, which can be confirmed with a muscle biopsy. 
❌ Repeat expansion analysis of the DMPK gene:
Incorrect: Myotonic dystrophy is in the differential for a patient presenting with weakness. However, this patient has no evidence of the commonly associated temporal and masseter muscle wasting, and he has persistent, predominantly distal weakness, which suggests inclusion body myositis—a diagnosis that can be confirmed with a muscle biopsy. 
❌ Serum potassium level:
Incorrect: Both hypo- and hyperkalemic periodic paralysis are in the differential for a patient presenting with weakness. However, this patient’s persistent, predominantly distal weakness suggests inclusion body myositis, which can be confirmed with a muscle biopsy.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of worsening weakness for the past two months. She has noted difficulty brushing her hair, rising from a chair, and has occasionally choked while eating dinner. Additionally, her eyelids have appeared droopy while applying her makeup for the past week. This morning, she developed double vision and slurred speech. Past medical history is noncontributory, and she takes no regular medication. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. On exam, she appears alert with hypophonic speech. She has bilateral ptosis, neck flexor weakness, and weakness of the bilateral shoulder abductors and hip flexors. Sensation is intact. What is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of myasthenia gravis, characterized by painless and fluctuating weakness, ptosis, diplopia, dysarthria, and dysphagia. Neuromuscular junction dysfunction can affect the muscles of respiration; therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to assess respiratory muscle strength through bedside pulmonary function tests (PFTs), such as measurement of negative inspiratory force. These patients should also have intravenous (IV) access established and undergo continuous vital sign monitoring.

Neuromuscular junction disorders often present with painless muscle weakness, ocular symptoms (e.g. double vision), or bulbar symptoms affecting speech or swallowing. Physical examination may reveal cranial nerve impairment (e.g., ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and facial muscle weakness), as well as neck and proximal limb weakness, while sensation remains intact.

The first step in evaluating a patient suspected of having a neuromuscular junction disorder is to look for signs of diaphragmatic weakness. If unrecognized, this may lead to rapid respiratory failure. Bedside pulmonary function tests may reveal reduced vital capacity, maximal inspiratory pressure (negative inspiratory force), and maximal expiratory pressure. Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation or intubation may be necessary to stabilize the airway and breathing if these findings are present.

Option Analysis

✅ Negative inspiratory force:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thyroid stimulating hormone level:
Incorrect: Weakness can be a sign of thyroid dysfunction; however, this patient presents with symptoms of neuromuscular junction dysfunction, which can affect diaphragmatic strength and respiration. Due to the risk of rapid respiratory decline, bedside pulmonary function testing should be the priority.
❌ Creatine kinase level:
Incorrect: Although a creatine kinase level may be elevated in patients with weakness, the priority is to perform bedside pulmonary function testing first as respiratory muscle involvement can rapidly lead to respiratory failure.
❌ Electromyogram and nerve conduction study:
Incorrect: Electrophysiology tests can prove helpful in the evaluation of a patient presenting with weakness, but acute management for patients with a neuromuscular junction disorder is to assess the strength of the muscles of respiration through bedside pulmonary function tests.
❌ Chest radiograph:
Incorrect: Chest radiography is helpful in the evaluation of a patient with respiratory distress, but only after immediate stabilization of the airway and breathing. This patient is at risk for respiratory failure secondary to neuromuscular junction dysfunction, for which bedside pulmonary function tests are indicated.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by emergency medical services for evaluation of lethargy. Her roommate found her slumped in her desk chair, poorly responsive, and ill-appearing. Past medical history is notable for major depressive disorder for which she inconsistently takes citalopram. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/85 mmHg. On exam, she appears alert and endorses nausea and double vision. She has bilateral ptosis, dysarthria, diaphoresis, watery eyes, and drooling. She has difficulty getting out of bed after an episode of emesis and fecal incontinence. Her complete blood count (CBC) with differential, comprehensive metabolic profile (CMP), urine toxicology screen, and serum hCG are unremarkable. Which of the following additional diagnostic tests can help confirm the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: Positive response to administration of atropine
Serum anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) and anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies
Improvement of symptoms with administration of edrophonium

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of organophosphate toxicity as evidenced by painless, nonfluctuating weakness alongside a cholinergic toxidrome (diaphoresis, salivation, lacrimation, diarrhea, and emesis). Organophosphates are widely used in certain pesticides, and ingestion or exposure can be inadvertent or may occur during a suicide attempt. Such exposure to these compounds leads to inhibition of acetylcholinesterase (AChE) at the neuromuscular junction (NMJ). Administration of atropine, a muscarinic receptor antagonist, can improve cholinergic symptoms and support the diagnosis.

In evaluating a possible neuromuscular junction (NMJ) disorder, the presence or absence of symptom fluctuation is key. Additional diagnostic tools that can help differentiate between various etiologies include an ice pack test, nerve conduction studies, electromyography (EMG), and antibody assays (e.g., anti–AChR, anti–MuSK, anti-VGCC) are helpful in diagnosing disorders like myasthenia gravis and Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome – both of which characteristically fluctuate and often improve with tests that enhance NMJ transmission (e.g. edrophonium test).

In contrast, organophosphate poisoning and botulism tend to present with nonfluctuating weakness, although their associated gastrointestinal symptoms help distinguish them. Botulism typically presents with constipation and a positive C. botulinum culture, whereas organophosphate toxicity causes vomiting and diarrhea, and responds to atropine or pralidoxime.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/  for international resources. You are not alone.  
 

Option Analysis

✅ Positive response to administration of atropine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Serum anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) and anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies:
Incorrect: This patient’s cholinergic symptoms are concerning for organophosphate toxicity, which causes inhibition of acetylcholinesterase. These symptoms typically improve with the administration of atropine. Anti-AChR and anti-MuSK antibodies are seen with myasthenia gravis, a fluctuating neuromuscular junction disorder.
❌ Serum anti-voltage-gated calcium channel (VGCC) antibodies:
Incorrect: This patient’s cholinergic symptoms are concerning for organophosphate toxicity. These symptoms should improve with the administration of atropine. Anti-VGCC antibodies are seen with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, a fluctuating neuromuscular junction disorder.
❌ Improvement of symptoms with administration of edrophonium:
Incorrect: A positive edrophonium test suggests either myasthenia gravis or Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome and can actually worsen the symptoms of acetylcholinesterase inhibition due to organophosphate toxicity.
❌ Positive Clostridium botulinum stool culture:
Incorrect: This patient’s cholinergic symptoms of vomiting and diarrhea are concerning for organophosphate toxicity, which should improve with administration of atropine. In contrast, botulism typically presents with constipation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of numbness and tingling in the right hand, which has been present for the past three weeks. The patient has difficulty buttoning shirts and experiences increased pain as a receptionist. Past medical history is non-contributory, and the patient takes no medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 116/72 mmHg. The patient endorses numbness over the palm, thumb, and first two fingers. There is weakness with thumb abduction. Phalen and Tinel signs are positive. Which of the following historical findings may contribute to this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of compressive median neuropathy, or carpal tunnel syndrome, as evidenced by numbness, tingling, pain, and weakness of the first three fingers, which worsen with repetitive motions. Pregnant individuals are at increased risk of developing this condition due to hormonal changes, fluid retention, and ligament softening.  

Compressive neuropathies occur due to mechanical entrapment of peripheral nerves, resulting in paresthesias, pain, or weakness. Without treatment, this can result in demyelination and axonal injury. Specific nerve impingement syndromes can impair the ability to perform everyday tasks, such as difficulty using the hands or experiencing foot drop or toe dragging while walking.

Certain medical conditions predispose patients to compressive neuropathies, including diabetes, hypothyroidism, obesity, pregnancy, trauma, and rheumatoid arthritis. Additionally, activities such as cycling, playing a musical instrument, maintaining certain positions for prolonged periods, or wearing tight clothing can precipitate compression.   

Option Analysis

✅ Pregnancy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Smoking:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation suggests compressive median neuropathy, which can occur with pregnancy due to hormonal changes, fluid retention, and ligament softening. Smoking is not a known risk factor for this condition.
❌ Caffeine use:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation suggests compressive median neuropathy, which can occur with pregnancy because of hormonal changes, fluid retention, and ligament softening. Caffeine use is not a known risk factor for this condition.
❌ Anxiety:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation suggests compressive median neuropathy, which can occur with pregnancy because of hormonal changes, fluid retention, and ligament softening. Anxiety is not a known risk factor for this condition.
❌ Injury to the elbow:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation suggests compressive median neuropathy, which can occur with pregnancy because of hormonal changes, fluid retention, and ligament softening. Compression at the elbow is more likely to cause ulnar neuropathy, which would affect the 4th and 5th fingers.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to acute onset back pain. Two hours ago, she was at home when she suddenly felt a sharp pain in the back after coughing. The patient describes a dull pain, 3/10 in severity, along the thoracic area. She has not had any recent weight loss, and she does not have bowel and bladder symptoms. Medical history is significant for smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 35 years. Family history is negative for cancer. The patient’s recent mammography from a year ago was normal. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. BMI is 19 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. On physical examination, marked kyphosis is noted and there is a focal tenderness over the thoracic vertebrae. The rest of the physical examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
This patient is a postmenopausal woman with significant risk factors (low BMI, increased age) presenting with acute onset back pain following a non-traumatic event (cough). She most likely has a compression fracture secondary to osteoporosis. The next best step in management of a suspected fracture without neurological deficit is confirmation with a plain radiograph. If there are signs of spinal cord compression (e.g. loss of sphincter control), urgent MRI or CT is indicated.  

Osteoporotic fractures (also known as fragility fractures and low-trauma fractures) describes fractures due to non-traumatic events (e.g. cough) or minor trauma (e.g. fall from a standing height or less). In some individuals, vertebral compression occurs slowly over time and is asymptomatic. Those with acute fractures usually present with an acute onset of midline back pain which may radiate to the flank, anterior abdomen, or posterior superior iliac spine. Radiation to the legs, as seen in disc herniation, is uncommon.  

Vertebral compression fractures are the most common type of osteoporotic fracture. The diagnosis of osteoporosis can be made via two ways: 1) demonstrating a T-score ≤ -2.5 standard deviations on dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan, or 2) clinically in patients presenting with fragility fracture. Management of an acute osteoporotic vertebral compression fracture includes pain control, activity modification, education, brace, surgery (e.g. vertebroplasty), and treatment of the underlying osteoporosis. For most postmenopausal women with osteoporosis, first-line therapy includes bisphosphonates (e.g., alendronate, risedronate).  



Option Analysis

❌ MRI of the spine:
Incorrect: A CT or MRI can be performed after an x-ray and laboratory testing are obtained if there is still concern for an underlying malignancy. Alternatively, in the setting of neurologic abnormalities (e.g. loss of sphincter control), an urgent MRI or CT would also be indicated. However, it would not be the first step in the evaluation of a fragility fracture in a patient with no neurologic deficits.
❌ CT of the spine:
Incorrect: A CT or MRI can be performed after an x-ray and laboratory testing are obtained if there is still concern for an underlying malignancy. Alternatively, in the setting of neurologic abnormalities (e.g. loss of sphincter control), an urgent MRI or CT would also be indicated. However, it would not be the first step in the evaluation of a fragility fracture in a patient with no neurologic deficits.
❌ PET-CT:
Incorrect: PET-CT can be used for cancer staging, assessing response to therapy, and searching for an occult primary lesion. However, even if the patient’s fracture is due to cancer metastasis, plain radiograph would still be the first test to obtain.
✅ X-ray of the spine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry:
Incorrect: A dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) bone density study should be performed to assess the severity of osteoporosis. However, osteoporosis can be clinically diagnosed in patients with a fragility fracture (from minor trauma). Also, a DEXA scan is not appropriate for the work-up of an acute fragility fracture.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman G1P1 comes to the clinic due to insidious onset of back pain over the past few weeks. She did not seek care because she thought it would pass by itself. A month ago, she gave birth to a healthy boy at 37 weeks of gestation. She received epidural anesthesia. After birth, she started having back pain and has had difficulty performing chores around the house and taking care of the baby. During the past 2 weeks, the back pain increased in severity, and she started having fevers. She has no bowel or bladder symptoms. The patient’s temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, she appears uncomfortable and has difficulty ambulating. Motor strength is 5/5, and sensation is intact on both lower extremities. Patellar and Achilles reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. There is focal tenderness and muscle spasm at the L1-L2 levels. Laboratory results show a WBC count of 10,000/mm<sup>3</sup> and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 100mm/hr. Which of the following is the most appropriate step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Empiric treatment with vancomycin and ceftriaxone

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with insidious onset of back pain following an epidural procedure, normal WBC count, elevated ESR, and focal tenderness on the lumbar spine. These factors raise concerns for vertebral osteomyelitis. In this condition, WBC count may be elevated or normal.  

Bacteria can reach the vertebrae through hematogenous spread from a distant infection site, direct inoculation from trauma (e.g., invasive spinal procedures, spinal surgery), or contiguous spread from an adjacent soft tissue infection (e.g. psoas abscess). The most common cause of vertebral osteomyelitis is Staphylococcus aureus, accounting for more than 50% of cases. Other causes include enteric gram-negative bacilli, viridans Streptococci, Streptococcus bovis, Enterococci, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and brucellosis.  

The cardinal clinical manifestation of vertebral osteomyelitis is pain localized to the affected area, which is exacerbated by movement or percussion. The pain may radiate to the leg, abdomen, scrotum, groin, or perineum. The pain typically has an insidious onset and worsens over weeks to months. Fever is often absent and therefore not a reliable finding.  

Laboratory tests may show elevated ESR and CRP, as well as normal or elevated WBC count. MRI is the most sensitive test for diagnosing vertebral osteomyelitis and epidural abscesses. If MRI is not available, CT may be used. A definitive diagnosis is established via a positive culture obtained from CT-guided biopsy of the affected area. Treatment includes prolonged antibiotic therapy (empiric initially, pathogen-specific following culture). Surgery may be warranted in the presence of neurologic deficits, abscess, cord compression, or recurrent/chronic infection.  



Option Analysis

✅ MRI of the spine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ X-ray of the spine:
Incorrect: Plain radiographs are often normal in the early phases of vertebral osteomyelitis and therefore not used. It may be used for the diagnosis of compression fractures, vertebral metastases, and ankylosing spondylitis.
❌ Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and reassurance:
Incorrect: An empiric trial of NSAIDs is suitable for patients with nonspecific acute back pain or acute lumbar radiculopathy. However, this patient's history and laboratory results raise concerns for an underlying infection, and therefore, NSAID therapy is not appropriate.  
❌ Empiric treatment with vancomycin and ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Empiric treatment with vancomycin and ceftriaxone is appropriate for the treatment of vertebral osteomyelitis as it covers the most common organisms including Staphylococci, Streptococci, and gram-negative bacilli. However, empiric treatment is typically given after MRI and blood cultures are obtained.
❌ Dexamethasone:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids are used in neoplastic epidural spinal cord compression as a bridge to definitive treatment and pain reduction. It is not used in the setting of vertebral osteomyelitis. While metastases to the spine from breast cancer are possible, the patient's history of an epidural procedure favors another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents to his primary care provider to evaluate lower back pain. The symptoms began two days ago after he attempted to lift a heavy bookshelf. The patient has not experienced incontinence or muscular weakness in the lower extremities. He currently rates the pain as 5 out of 10 in severity.  His past medical history is notable for hypertension, for which he takes amlodipine and lisinopril. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 135/73 mmHg, and pulse is 62/min. On physical examination, there is mild tenderness over the lumbar paraspinal muscles. Pain is exacerbated with flexion and extension of the lumbar spine. Strength and sensation are intact in the bilateral lower extremities. The remainder of the physical exam is noncontributory. Laboratory testing is shown below. The patient is prescribed a short course of cyclobenzaprine. Which of the following side effects is associated with this medication?
 
Laboratory Value
Results (U.S. conventional units)
Results (SI units)
Hemoglobin
15.1 g/dL
9.38 mmol/L
Leukocyte Count
7,500/mm3
7.5*109/L
Platelet count
270,000/mm3
270*109/L
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)

questions.solution:
This patient presents with musculoskeletal low back pain that has persisted despite applying heat packs and ibuprofen use. As a result, he was started on cyclobenzaprine, which can cause xerostomia as a side effect.

Cyclobenzaprine is a centrally-acting muscle relaxant. Its exact mechanism of action is not fully understood, but studies have demonstrated that the medication antagonizes 5-HT2 receptors within the spinal cord. A similar medication is methocarbamol (its mechanism of action also remains unclear).

Both cyclobenzaprine and methocarbamol can treat musculoskeletal pain (e.g., low back pain, neck pain). In addition, cyclobenzaprine can be used off-label to treat fibromyalgia.

These medications can cause decreased skeletal muscle tone, sedation, drowsiness, confusion, and visual hallucinations. Furthermore, cyclobenzaprine can cause anticholinergic side effects, such as xerostomia, mydriasis, hyperthermia, and constipation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Truncal obesity:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids can be used to treat inflammatory myopathies such as dermatomyositis and polymyositis. These medications can result in the redistribution of adipose tissue from the extremities to the abdomen and subsequent truncal obesity. This patient has a normal ESR and creatinine kinase, making an inflammatory myopathy unlikely.  
❌ Diarrhea:
Incorrect: This patient was prescribed cyclobenzaprine, a centrally-acting muscle relaxant. Cyclobenzaprine also has anticholinergic properties. As a result, the medication can cause constipation, not diarrhea.  
❌ Miosis:
Incorrect: Opioids are a class of pain medications that can cause miosis. These medications bind to mu, kappa, and gamma opioid receptors. In contrast, this patient was started on cyclobenzaprine, a centrally-acting muscle relaxant. Cyclobenzaprine has anticholinergic properties and can cause mydriasis, not miosis.  
✅ Xerostomia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Myoclonus:
Incorrect: This patient was started on cyclobenzaprine to treat low back pain. Serotonin syndrome may develop in patients taking cyclobenzaprine and another pro-serotonergic medication. In contrast, serotonin syndrome would be highly unlikely in patients on cyclobenzaprine monotherapy.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of back pain that began 12 hours ago. The patient was picking up a bag of groceries when her symptoms started. She was recently diagnosed with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Her medications include abemaciclib and anastrozole. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 155/78 mmHg. Physical exam reveals focal tenderness over the lumbar spine. The pain is exacerbated with flexion and extension of the spine. No neurologic deficits are noted in the lower extremities. Imaging is ordered and shown below. Her most recent lab results showed a leukocyte count of 3,600/mm3. Administration of which medications would have most likely prevented this patient’s condition?
 
Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient has an L1 spinal compression fracture in the setting of anastrozole use. Anastrozole is a type II aromatase inhibitor (AI) that prevents the conversion of androgens to estrogen. It is used to treat estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer in postmenopausal women.

Since estrogen helps sustain bone density, patients on AIs are deprived of its protective effects. This can increase their risk of developing osteopenia, osteoporosis, and arthralgias. Osteopenia/osteoporosis predisposes patients to develop fractures. Bisphosphonates, which reduce bone reuptake by interfering with osteoclast activity, should be administered together with AIs in patients with osteopenia/osteoporosis to prevent such events.  

Option Analysis

❌ Vancomycin:
Incorrect: Vancomycin can be used to prevent or treat infections caused by gram-positive bacteria. Vertebral osteomyelitis can cause focal tenderness over the spine. However, this patient’s MRI shows loss of height in the L1 vertebra, which is more consistent with a compression fracture.  
❌ Piperacillin-tazobactam:
Incorrect: Piperacillin-tazobactam is a broad-spectrum antibiotic with gram-positive, gram-negative, and anaerobic coverage. However, piperacillin-tazobactam would not be useful in preventing a vertebral compression fracture.
✅ Alendronate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Raloxifene:
Incorrect: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM). It is an estrogen antagonist in the breast and endometrium but an estrogen agonist in the bones. Raloxifene can be used for breast cancer and osteoporosis prevention. Its efficacy in providing osteoporosis prophylaxis for patients taking aromatase inhibitors is not well documented.  
❌ Denosumab:
Incorrect: Denosumab can reduce the risk of osteoporosis and spinal compression fractures. However, bisphosphonates (e.g. alendronate) are the first-line option for preventing osteoporosis and fractures in patients taking an aromatase inhibitor.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic with a 4-month history of low back pain. He describes the pain as a dull, aching sensation that worsens with prolonged standing or walking and improves with rest. The pain is localized to his lower back and does not radiate to his legs. There has not been recent trauma or heavy lifting. There is no numbness, tingling, or weakness in his lower extremities, and he has not had bowel or bladder incontinence, fever, or weight loss. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes, both well-controlled with amlodipine and metformin, respectively. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient has a normal gait but appears uncomfortable when standing upright. There is tenderness to palpation over the lumbar paraspinal muscles and the lumbar spinous processes. Range of motion is limited, especially in lumbar extension and rotation, which reproduces his pain. Neurological examination is unremarkable, with normal strength, sensation, and reflexes in the lower extremities. Straight leg testing is negative bilaterally. An x-ray is performed and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

Image by Nevit Dilmen, crop and annotation by Mikael Häggström, M.D. Licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported license. Reproduced from WikiCommons
questions.solution:
The patient's chronic, non-radiating low back pain that worsens with extension and rotation, combined with a normal neurological examination and absence of red flag symptoms, is suggestive of spondylosis. Spondylosis is a degenerative condition characterized by the wear and tear of the intervertebral discs and facet joints, commonly presenting with pain that worsens with specific movements and improvement with rest. The radiograph obtained in this patient demonstrates osteophytes, which are classic findings in spondylosis. Other findings consistent with spondylosis include decreased intervertebral disc space, and facet joint hypertrophy.

The diagnostic workup for an adult with mechanical back pain begins with taking a detailed history and physical examination to identify the nature and characteristics of the pain, along with any red flag symptoms. Plain X-rays can detect bony abnormalities like spinal fractures, spondylolysis, and spondylolisthesis. Spondylolysis often presents with a "Scotty dog" sign on oblique X-rays, while spondylolisthesis shows vertebral displacement. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the gold standard for evaluating soft tissue structures and differentiating between causes of low back pain. Findings associated with spinal stenosis include narrowing of the spinal canal with neural impingement. Findings associated with disc herniation include protrusion or extrusion of intervertebral discs causing nerve root compression. Findings seen with spondylosis include degenerative changes like disc space narrowing, osteophytes, and facet joint hypertrophy. MRI is critical in the workup of low back pain with red flag features and should be performed urgently when any red flags are present. Muscle strain or sprain is typically diagnosed clinically with a history of recent overuse or injury and physical exam findings of localized tenderness and muscle spasm without neurological deficits.    

Option Analysis

✅ Spondylosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Muscle strain:
Incorrect: Patients with muscle strain generally present with acute, diffuse back pain following overexertion or injury, often with paraspinal muscle spasms. This patient's history of chronic pain and the absence of a precipitating event make muscle strain less likely. 
❌ Cauda equina syndrome  :
Incorrect: Patients with cauda equina syndrome typically present with severe low back pain, saddle anesthesia, bowel or bladder incontinence, and significant neurological deficits. This patient does not exhibit any of these symptoms, making this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ S1 spinal fracture:
Incorrect: Spinal fractures typically present with acute onset of severe, localized pain following trauma or in patients with risk factors for osteoporosis. The patient’s chronic, activity-related pain without a history of trauma or osteoporosis risk factors is more indicative of a degenerative condition like spondylosis.  
❌ L5-S1 disc herniation:
Incorrect: Disc herniation commonly causes acute radicular pain, numbness, tingling, and possibly weakness in the extremities, usually associated with a positive straight leg raise test. The patient’s chronic pain is localized without radicular symptoms, making disc herniation less likely.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of chronic back pain. The patient has been experiencing worsening back pain over the past five months which is what brought them into the clinic. The patient has not experienced any sensory changes or bowel or bladder loss of control. She has no difficulty walking. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, obesity, and osteoporosis. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for anterior pelvic tilt, and increased curvature of the lumbar spine without abnormalities in the rest of the spine. The patient has full range of motion of the lumbar spine without pain. A radiograph is obtained and shown below. Which of the following best describes this patient’s findings?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of worsening chronic back pain and is found to have an anterior pelvic tilt and excessive curvature of the lumbar spine on physical examination. Furthermore, radiography demonstrates excessive lumbar lordosis or an increase in inward curvature of the lumbar vertebrae.  

The spine's normal curvature typically follows four normal curvatures, which can be seen on a lateral view radiograph. These include thoracic and sacral kyphosis. Kyphosis is an increased front to back curve of the spine giving a convex curve in the spine (i.e., convexity towards the back of the spine). in those areas. There is also a normal cervical and lumbar lordosis giving a gently concave curve in those areas (i.e, concavity towards the back of the spine). Two common spinal abnormalities include excessive thoracic or thoracolumbar kyphosis and excessive lumbar lordosis.  

Excessive kyphosis typically occurs in the thoracic region and leads to a hunchback appearance. This process can be postural or due to vertebral compression fractures from osteoporosis, osteoarthritis, or spondylolisthesis. Additional etiologies include genetic disorders such as Scheuermann kyphosis, osteogenesis imperfecta, or metabolic or congenital disabilities like spina bifida.  

Excessive lumbar lordosis results in the presence of an anterior pelvic tilt or swayback posture on physical examination. It is most often due to poor posture, obesity, weak hamstrings, tight hip flexors, or osteoporosis. Like excessive kyphosis, excessive lumbar lordosis is also associated with several genetic disorders, including Ehlers-Danlos syndrome and achondroplasia. It can lead to lumbar pain and if untreated, excessive lumbar lordosis may result in slippage of intervertebral discs, radiculopathy, and spondylolisthesis.

Option Analysis

✅ Excessive lumbar lordosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Excessive thoracolumbar kyphosis:
Incorrect: Thoracolumbar kyphosis refers to excessive thoracic/lumbar convexity seen in the sagittal plane.. This finding is  not present in this patient’s radiograph or examination. Patients with thoracic or thoracolumbar kyphosis have exaggerated forward rounding of the upper back on physical exam  
❌ Scoliosis:
Incorrect: Scoliosis refers to an abnormal curvature of the spine in the coronal plane, resulting in lateral displacement of the spine. It is difficult to evaluate for scoliosis on a lateral spinal radiograph, however this patient does not have abnormal lateral curvature of the spine on physical examination.  
❌ Spondylolisthesis:
Incorrect: Spondylosis refers to an anatomic defect or fracture of the pars interarticularis. Spondylosis may progress to spondylolisthesis, characterized by anterior displacement of the vertebral body. This patient’s radiograph does not demonstrate spondylolisthesis.  
❌ Vertebral body compression fracture:
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of osteoporosis, the radiograph does not demonstrate evidence of a compression fracture. It shows excessive curvature of the lumbar spine.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to worsening fever and night sweats over several days. The patient has also had worsening back pain and unintentional weight loss of 22 lbs. (10 kg) over the past few months. Past medical history is significant for untreated HIV. She does not use tobacco, alcohol or recreational drugs. She frequently travels to South Asia to visit family. Temperature is 38.9 ºC (102.0 ºF),  pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 145/89 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears cachectic and ill, but she is in no acute distress. Cardiac exam is within normal limits. Lung sounds are clear to auscultation. There is point tenderness over several lumbar spinous processes. There is decreased sensation in both lower extremities. A chest radiograph shows no abnormalities.
