Incorrect: Low body-mass index (BMI) can increase an individual's risk of developing osteoporosis. However, in patients with a healthy BMI, weight gain itself is not recommended as prophylaxis against osteoporosis because increased body weight can lead to other comorbidities, including osteoarthritis, hypertension, cardiovascular disease, and sleep apnea.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman comes to the office because of left hip pain and stiffness. The pain is dull but constant and has not responded to over-the-counter medications. The patient has no associated muscle weakness or sensory loss. She lives at home alone and has also experienced some weight loss and decreased hearing over the past few months. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and obesity. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 167/98 mmHg. Physical examination reveals mild bilateral hearing loss but is otherwise unremarkable. Laboratory results are shown below. Radiography reveals cortical thickening of the left femur. Bone scintigraphy shows increased radioactive uptake at various sites, including the left femur. Which of the following is the next best step in managing this patient?  

 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Serum Chemistries 
 Alkaline phosphatase  420 U/L 
 Creatinine  1 mg/dL 
 Calcium  8.8 mg/dL 
 25-hydroxy vitamin D  35 ng/mL

choices.text: Doppler ultrasound of the left lower extremity

questions.solution:
This patient presents with left hip pain and hearing loss, which, combined with the imaging findings, are consistent with the Paget disease of the bone. The condition is a disorder of osteoclastic bone resorption. Bisphosphonates are the preferred treatment option.  

Bisphosphonates can be subdivided into two main groups, as outlined in the table below.  



Bisphosphonates work by binding to hydroxyapatite, the mineralized form of calcium found in bones. When osteoclasts break down bones, they also take in the bisphosphonates. The medication interferes with osteoclast function and promotes osteoclast apoptosis, thereby suppressing bone turnover.  

Bisphosphonates are used to treat Paget disease of bone, osteogenesis imperfecta, and hypercalcemia secondary to certain malignancies. Chronic bisphosphonate therapy is also used to prevent and treat osteoporosis. The medication has been shown to increase bone density and reduce the likelihood of fractures.

Option Analysis

❌ Corticosteroid therapy :
Incorrect: Corticosteroid therapy is a suitable treatment for managing hypercalcemia in granulomatous disease. It is ineffective in decreasing bone resorption by osteoclasts in Paget disease of the bone.  
❌ Referral to orthopedic surgery:
Incorrect: Referral to an orthopedic surgeon for bone biopsy would be appropriate for a suspected bone tumor. Radiography of the affected extremity may show a sunburst appearance secondary to periosteal reaction. This patient’s findings are more suggestive of Paget disease of the bone.  
✅ Bisphosphonates therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Doppler ultrasound of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect: A Doppler ultrasound of the left lower extremity would be an appropriate next step for evaluating deep vein thrombosis, which usually presents with leg pain and swelling. Hearing loss and weight loss are not typically seen.  
❌ Infliximab therapy:
Incorrect: Infliximab is an anti-tumor necrosis factor therapy that effectively manages autoimmune conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, and Crohn disease. In contrast, infliximab is not effective in treating Paget disease of the bone.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the office for an annual physical checkup. The patient is asymptomatic. Her past medical history is significant for seasonal allergies, for which she takes loratadine. She had an uncomplicated cholecystectomy 25 years ago. Last menstrual period was 12 years ago. Family history is significant for breast cancer in the patient’s grandmother. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. The patient is given the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine and shingles vaccine. A dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan reveals a T-score of -2.7. The patient is started on denosumab. This medication inhibits osteoclast formation and activity by binding to which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient’s DEXA scan is suggestive of osteoporosis. Denosumab can be administered for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis.  

Denosumab is a human monoclonal antibody that binds the RANK ligand (RANKL) and inhibits its binding to RANK receptors on the surface of osteoclasts and their precursors. These effects prevent the activation and maturation of osteoclasts, which ultimately limits bone breakdown.    

In addition to treating postmenopausal osteoporosis, denosumab can be administered to prevent skeletal-related events (e.g., bone pain, fractures) in patients with bone metastases.  

Common side effects include hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and infections. Rarely can the medication cause osteonecrosis of the jaw.  



Option Analysis

❌ Calcium-sensing receptors:
Incorrect: Cinacalcet lowers parathyroid hormone levels by activating the calcium-sensing receptors in the parathyroid glands. It is effective in treating hypercalcemia in parathyroid cancer and secondary hyperparathyroidism in chronic kidney disease.  
❌ Hydroxyapatite crystal:
Incorrect: Bisphosphonates (e.g. alendronate) reduce both the resorption and formation by binding to hydroxyapatite, which is the mineralized form of calcium found in bones. When osteoclasts break down bones, they also take in the bisphosphonates. The medication interferes with osteoclast function and promotes osteoclast apoptosis, thereby suppressing bone turnover. Denosumab is not a bisphosphonate and works via a different mechanism of action.  
✅ RANK ligand:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Calcitonin receptors:
Incorrect: Calcitonin binds to calcitonin receptors and inhibits bone resorption. In contrast, denosumab’s mechanism of action does not involve calcitonin receptors.  
❌ Parathyroid hormone receptors:
Incorrect: Teriparatide is a parathyroid hormone (PTH) analog that acts through PTH receptors. When administered in a pulsatile fashion, the medication can promote osteoblastic activity and bone formation. In contrast, denosumab does not bind PTH receptors.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by family members because of increasing confusion over the past two days. The patient also has experienced nausea as well as back and abdominal pain. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and amlodipine. Family history is significant for prostate cancer in the patient’s father. He has a 25-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 135/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows a disheveled and confused man. Lung fields are clear to auscultation bilaterally, and heart sounds are normal. A chest radiograph is obtained and is unremarkable. There are no focal neurological deficits. Laboratory results are shown below. In addition to normal saline, which of the following should be administered to this patient?  


Laboratory Value  Result
Complete Blood Count 
Hematocrit  42% 
 Leukocytes  8,000/mm3 
 Platelet  170,000/mm3 
Serum Chemistries 
Sodium  138 mEq/L 
 Potassium  3.8 mEq/L 
 Chloride  100 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  2 mg/dL 
 Calcium  14.2 mg/dL 
 Glucose  138 mg/dL 
 Blood urea nitrogen   40 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient has symptomatic hypercalcemia, as evidenced by the history of confusion, abdominal pain, and back pain. Patients with hypercalcemia require saline hydration to restore intravascular volume and facilitate urine calcium excretion. Calcitonin, a peptide hormone, can be administered concurrently.  

Calcitonin works by directly inhibiting osteoclast activity, thereby decreasing bone breakdown. At the same time, calcitonin stimulates osteoblasts to build more bones. It also decreases the concentration of serum calcium and phosphate by increasing their excretion via the kidneys.  

There are two types of calcitonin, synthetic human calcitonin, and synthetic salmon calcitonin. Synthetic salmon calcitonin, also known as salcatonin, is more convenient due to its longer half-life and potency.    

Calcitonin can be administered by injection or intranasally. It is indicated in the treatment of postmenopausal and corticosteroid-induced osteoporosis, hypercalcemia, and Paget disease of the bone. Adverse effects of calcitonin use include flushing, dizziness, paresthesia, and gastrointestinal disturbances.  



Option Analysis

✅ Calcitonin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics increase renal tubule reabsorption of calcium, leading to an increase in serum calcium levels and a decrease in urine calcium concentration. This patient’s symptoms are likely due to hypercalcemia, so thiazide diuretics should be avoided.  
❌ Lithium:
Incorrect: Patients receiving chronic lithium therapy often develop mild hypercalcemia. This side effect is most likely because of increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion due to an increase in the set point at which calcium suppresses PTH release. Lithium is not indicated in the management of hypercalcemia.  
❌ Insulin:
Incorrect: Insulin is effective in driving potassium into the cells and can be used to treat hyperkalemia, but not hypercalcemia.  
❌ Glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids are effective in managing hypercalcemia secondary to granulomatous diseases such as sarcoidosis. In contrast, this patient does not have a history of sarcoidosis, and chest imaging is unremarkable. As a result, calcitonin would be more effective in managing hypercalcemia in this patient.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for a wellness checkup. The patient recently had a dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan that placed her at two standard deviations below the mean for bone density and is following up today to discuss the results. Past medical history is notable for asthma, anxiety, irritable bowel syndrome, and radial fracture that occurred 5-months ago following a ground-level fall. Current medications include clonazepam and albuterol. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient is started on raloxifene in addition to weight-bearing exercise and vitamins. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal woman is started on raloxifene, a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM), to treat postmenopausal osteoporosis.    

Raloxifene has a partial agonist effect on estrogen receptors in the bones. Therefore it is useful in the treatment of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women. In addition, it is an estrogen receptor antagonist in the endometrium and breast tissue. As a result, raloxifene can also be used to prevent breast cancer.      

Common side effects include hot flashes and an increased risk of venous thrombosis.   

 

Option Analysis

❌ Endometrial cancer:
Incorrect: Tamoxifen, another selective estrogen receptor modulator, has an agonist effect on the endometrial receptors, promoting endometrial hyperplasia and increasing the risk of endometrial cancer. In contrast, raloxifene is an agonist at estrogen receptors in the bone but an antagonist at receptors in the endometrium.  
❌ Breast cancer:
Incorrect: Selective estrogen receptor modulators such as raloxifene are effective in treating hormone-responsive breast cancer, where it acts as an antagonist to prevent receptor activation by endogenous estrogens. It does not increase the risk of developing breast cancer.  
❌ Osteonecrosis of jaw:
Incorrect: Bisphosphonates are associated with osteonecrosis of the jaw. In contrast, raloxifene is not associated with this complication.   
✅ Deep vein thrombosis :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Osteosarcoma:
Incorrect: The use of teriparatide, a parathyroid hormone analog, in patients with Paget disease of the bone can increase the risk of developing osteosarcoma. In contrast, raloxifene is not associated with osteosarcoma.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman comes to the office because of persistent, dull bone pain. The patient has a history of metastatic breast cancer and is currently undergoing systemic chemotherapy. The pain is relieved occasionally by acetaminophen and oxycodone. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a right-sided mastectomy scar and a palpable right supraclavicular lymph node. Laboratory results are shown below. The patient is started on intravenous zoledronic acid. Is this patient at increased risk of developing one of the following symptoms?  

 Laboratory Value  Result
 Sodium  138 mEq/L 
 Potassium  3.8 mEq/L 
 Chloride  100 mEq/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase  420 U/L 
 Creatinine  1 mg/dL 
 Calcium  12 mg/dL 
 Glucose  138 mg/dL

choices.text: Swelling around the eyes and lips

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with hypercalcemia in the setting of metastatic breast cancer to the bone. She is started on bisphosphonate therapy.   

Oral bisphosphonates are most commonly associated with upper gastrointestinal side effects, such as esophagitis, esophageal ulcers, and gastric irritation. Individuals are advised to take oral bisphosphonates with plenty of water and stay upright for at least 30 minutes.  

On the other hand, intravenous bisphosphonates do not cause gastrointestinal disturbances but can lead to rare and more severe side effects, such as jaw osteonecrosis. 

 

Option Analysis

❌ Epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting:
Incorrect: Oral bisphosphonates are associated with upper gastrointestinal side effects, such as esophagitis, esophageal ulcers, and gastric irritation. Intravenous bisphosphonates do not typically cause gastrointestinal disturbances.
✅ Jaw pain and swelling:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Overgrowth of gum tissue  :
Incorrect: Gingival hyperplasia is a side effect of phenytoin and cyclosporine. It is not an adverse effect of bisphosphonates.  
❌ Exertional chest pain and tightness:
Incorrect: Triptans, the first-line treatment for migraines, can cause coronary vasospasm and chest pain exertions. In contrast, bisphosphonates do not cause vasoconstriction.  
❌ Swelling around the eyes and lips:
Incorrect: Angioedema can result from increased bradykinin production in patients receiving angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (e.g. lisinopril). Bisphosphonates do not increase bradykinin levels and would not cause these side effects.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for an annual visit. The patient has been feeling well with no new symptoms and takes his medications as prescribed. His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, well-controlled hypothyroidism, and HIV (most recent HIV RNA was undetectable). Current medications include metformin, synthroid, and bictegravir-emtricitabine-tenofovir. The patient required surgical fixation of a right humerus fracture nine years ago after falling off a ladder but has had no surgeries otherwise. The patient’s mother had osteopenia and diabetes mellitus. The patient does not use alcohol or tobacco but has used cocaine for the past year once every few months. Vital signs in the office are within normal limits. BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is an indication to screen this patient for osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of HIV has an increased risk of osteoporosis and should be screened with a DXA scan. Patients with HIV are at higher risk for osteopenia and osteoporosis, and the cause is likely multifactorial. Screening with a DXA scan is recommended for postmenopausal women with HIV and men > 50 years old with HIV.  

Osteoporosis refers to a condition of low bone density, decreased bone mass, and increased risk of fracture. Primary osteoporosis occurs due to bone loss associated with aging, especially in postmenopausal women due to low levels of sex hormones. Secondary osteoporosis occurs due to medical conditions (e.g., HIV, chronic kidney disease) or medications (e.g. long-term glucocorticoid use, certain antiretroviral therapies). The history should focus on assessing for significant risk factors, such as fractures without major trauma, BMI <20 kg/m2, osteopenia, family history of osteoporotic fractures, and smoking and alcohol use.  

Women > 65 years old, men > 70 years old, and patients who are > 50 years old who have risk factors for osteoporosis should be screened. Screening is accomplished with a dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scan. A T-score (standard deviation measure of bone density compared to a reference population) of -1.0 to -2.5 indicates osteopenia, or it can represent osteoporosis if the FRAX score meets criteria, and a T-score of < -2.5 indicates osteoporosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ HIV infection status:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism typically has minimal effect on bone mineral density, though it may cause bone loss with excess thyroid replacement therapy. Hyperthyroidism does lead to bone loss and osteoporosis. This patient’s hypothyroidism is well-controlled with thyroid replacement therapy.  
❌ BMI of 22 kg/m2:
Incorrect: A body mass index (BMI) <20 kg/m2 is a risk factor for osteoporosis. This patient’s BMI is not a significant risk factor.  
❌ Prior fracture history:
Incorrect: Fragility fractures that occur spontaneously or with minimal trauma are risk factors for developing osteoporosis. This patient had a fracture that was associated with significant trauma and thus is not at increased risk for osteoporosis.  
❌ Illicit substance use:
Incorrect: Consistent alcohol and tobacco use are strong risk factors for osteoporosis. Extensive cocaine use can lead to osteoporosis and muscle loss, however, this patient’s recent use of cocaine a few times during the year is not likely a strong risk factor.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the office for an annual physical examination. The patient has left hip pain, attributed to Paget disease of the bone diagnosed three years ago. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. The patient is allergic to penicillin. Her last menstrual period was ten years ago. Family history is significant for breast cancer in the patient’s grandmother. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient is given the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine and shingles vaccine. A dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan reveals a T-score of -2.7. The patient inquires about a new PTH-analogue, teriparatide. Which of the following is a contraindication to this medication in this patient?

choices.text: Personal history of Paget disease of the bone

questions.solution:
This patient’s DEXA scan reveals a T-score of -2.7, which is consistent with a diagnosis of osteoporosis. Teriparatide is an effective treatment option for postmenopausal osteoporosis. It is, however, contraindicated in this patient given her history of Paget disease of the bone.  

Teriparatide is a recombinant analog of the parathyroid hormone given subcutaneously once per day. When given in a pulsatile fashion, it works by stimulating osteoblasts and reducing their apoptosis, resulting in a net increase in bone formation.    

Common side effects include transient hypercalcemia and an increased risk of developing osteosarcoma. The medication should be avoided when the patient has other diseases that also increase the risk of developing osteosarcoma, such as those with Paget disease of bone.  




Option Analysis

❌ Family history of breast cancer:
Incorrect: Family history of breast cancer is not a contraindication to teriparatide.  
✅ Personal history of Paget disease of the bone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent pneumococcal vaccine administration:
Incorrect: Interaction between a vaccine and a drug has been reported only with the influenza vaccine and four drugs, which are aminopyrine, phenytoin sodium, theophylline, and warfarin sodium. The pneumococcal vaccine does not interact with teriparatide.  
❌ Penicillin allergy:
Incorrect: There is no cross-reactivity between penicillin and teriparatide.  
❌ Postmenopausal state:
Incorrect: Teriparatide is a suitable medication for treating postmenopausal osteoporosis. The medication can be safely administered to women in a postmenopausal state.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of fatigue, polyuria, and unintentional weight gain of 20 lbs (9.1 kg) over the past year. Her past medical history is significant for well-controlled hypertension treated with low-dose lisinopril. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 ºF), blood pressure is 162/95 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Physical examination is notable for central obesity, with lower abdominal striae and small ecchymoses scattered throughout. Laboratory studies are shown below. The serum cortisol does not suppress with low-dose dexamethasone but with high-dose dexamethasone. Brain MRI shows a large pituitary tumor. Abdominal CT imaging does not show adrenal abnormalities. DXA scan shows a T-score of -2.9. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

 Laboratory study  Result
 Finger stick blood glucose  209 mg/dL 
 Bedtime serum cortisol  12 µg/dL 
 Overnight salivary cortisol  0.63 µg/dL 
 25-hydroxy vitamin D  37 ng/mL (normal range: 30-70 ng/mL)

choices.text: Consult neurosurgery for removal of the pituitary mass
Repeat bone density scan in six months

questions.solution:
This patient has osteoporosis, as indicated by the T-score < -2.5. In this patient’s case, osteoporosis is likely caused by hypercortisolism due to an ACTH-producing pituitary tumor (Cushing disease). Management should first focus on diagnosing and treating the underlying secondary cause of osteoporosis. Therefore this patient should be seen by neurosurgery to evaluate for removal of the pituitary mass.  

Osteoporosis refers to a condition of low bone density, decreased bone mass, and increased risk of fracture. Primary osteoporosis occurs due to bone loss associated with aging, especially in postmenopausal women due to low levels of sex hormones. Secondary osteoporosis occurs due to medical conditions (severe hypercortisolism in this case) or medications (e.g. long-term glucocorticoid use).  

If secondary osteoporosis is diagnosed, the underlying condition should be managed before starting medications for osteoporosis. All patients diagnosed with osteopenia or osteoporosis should be checked for adequate calcium intake and serum vitamin D levels. Resistance training should be recommended to all patients with osteoporosis to improve bone density, muscle mass, and functional status. If patients with secondary causes of osteoporosis continue to have bone loss despite treatment of the underlying etiology, pharmacologic therapy may be warranted.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Consult neurosurgery for removal of the pituitary mass:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Prescribe alendronate:
Incorrect: While this patient may end up needing a bisphosphonate, the hypercortisolism from the pituitary tumor is causing secondary osteoporosis and should be addressed first.  
❌ Recommend resistance training:
Incorrect: While resistance training is beneficial for almost all patients and can significantly reduce the risk of osteoporosis and osteoporotic fractures, this patient’s pituitary mass should be addressed as soon as possible.  
❌ Prescribe high-dose ergocalciferol:
Incorrect: While this patient may benefit from vitamin D therapy, her current level is in the normal range and high-dose therapy is not necessary at this time. More importantly, the pituitary tumor is likely causing secondary osteoporosis, which should be addressed first.  
❌ Repeat bone density scan in six months:
Incorrect: This patient has osteoporosis with a likely secondary cause (pituitary mass causing hypercortisolism). There is no reason to wait and repeat imaging. The pituitary mass should be treated now.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic to follow up on recent bone density scan results. The patient’s bone density scan shows a T score of -2.8. Further workup shows no secondary cause of osteoporosis. The patient’s past medical history is significant for hypertension and severe chronic esophagitis with stenosis requiring frequent esophageal dilations. Her current medications include amlodipine, carvedilol, and pantoprazole. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears frail. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has osteoporosis as indicated by a T-score < -2.5. She also has an esophageal disorder which is a contraindication to taking bisphosphonates, which are typically the first-line treatment for osteoporosis. Denosumab, which is a RANK-ligand inhibitor, is an appropriate alternative agent to prescribe for this patient with osteoporosis at high risk for fracture.  

Management of osteoporosis includes making sure patients have adequate calcium intake and checking serum vitamin D levels and supplementing if necessary. Smoking cessation should be recommended for patients who smoke. Resistance training can significantly improve bone density, muscle mass, and functional status and should be recommended for all patients with osteoporosis. Bisphosphonates are antiresorptive agents that are generally the first-line option for treating osteoporosis. However, bisphosphonates are associated with some important side effects, such as pill-related esophagitis, osteonecrosis of the jaw, atypical femoral stress fractures, and renal toxicity. Denosumab (a RANK-ligand inhibitor) is an alternative antiresorptive therapy option for patients who are not candidates for bisphosphonates. In certain cases, including severe osteoporosis, anabolic therapy with teriparatide (a parathyroid hormone analogue) or romosozumab (monoclonal antibody sclerostin inhibitor) may be indicated. In certain postmenopausal women, estrogen-related therapy may be an option if there are contraindications to or intolerance of other agents.  

Option Analysis

✅ Prescribe subcutaneous denosumab:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Prescribe raloxifene:
Incorrect: Raloxifene is a type of estrogen-related therapy with anti-resorptive properties that can be used for the treatment of osteoporosis in certain post-menopausal women with contraindications or intolerance of other agents.  
❌ Prescribe oral alendronate:
Incorrect: This patient has an esophageal disorder and would not be a good candidate for oral bisphosphonates due to the significant risk for pill-related esophagitis.  
❌ Recommend resistance training:
Incorrect: This patient has osteoporosis and has a contraindication to taking oral bisphosphonates. Another pharmacologic agent should be started in addition to recommending lifestyle changes.  
❌ Recommend increasing dietary calcium intake:
Incorrect: This patient has osteoporosis and has a contraindication to taking oral bisphosphonates. Another pharmacologic agent should be started in addition to recommending lifestyle changes like resistance training and adequate calcium intake.
